news.title: The Chevrons struggle as Mulder breaks captaincy record
news.content:
Story by Raynald Ngwarati
THE South Africa national men’s cricket team, the Proteas have laid the foundation of a big first-innings score after closing the day on 465 runs for four in the opening day of the second Test match against Zimbabwe at Queens Sports Club in Bulawayo.
It was a tough day on the field for Zimbabwe’s Chevrons as the Proteas ran riot, spearheaded by a record-breaking innings from skipper Wiaan Mulder.
The South Africans, who lost two wickets early in the first hour after brilliant bowling from Tanaka Chivanga and Wellington Masakadza, masterminded an emphatic comeback to take control on day one.
Just like in the first match of the series, Chivanga got the early breakthrough for Zimbabwe, claiming the priced wicket of Toby de Zorzi for 10 runs before Masakadza dismissed debutant Lesego Senokwane for three runs, leaving South Africa reeling at 24 for two.
Mulder, however, was determined to turn the tide for his side.
Promoted to number three on the batting card and handed the captaincy, Mulder anchored the Proteas’ innings and led their fightback from 24 for two to a commanding score by stumps on day one.
He built a 184-run third-wicket stand with David Bedingham before unleashing his attacking flair in a 217-run partnership with Lhuan dre Pretorius for the fourth wicket, as South Africa dominated proceedings.
The skipper found boundaries with ease, exploiting Zimbabwe’s sloppy fielding end route to a record-breaking innings. He shattered a 57-year-old mark for the most runs scored on his debut as captain.

news.title: Scottland falls as CAPS United  clinchs derby victory
news.content:
Story by Raynald Ngwarati
HARARE giants, CAPS United, have kept Scottland’s ambitions at bay after beating the ambitious new boys by a solitary goal at Rufaro Stadium this Sunday.
After a lengthy social media battle, Scottland and CAPS United got a chance to settle their scores on the pitch this Sunday at their shared home venue, Rufaro Stadium.
Battling for derby bragging rights, the home team failed to live up to their nickname Mabviravira, as they were tamed on their turf by CAPS United.
Makepekepe, who have rediscovered their rhythm, placed faith in their mid-season signings, a move that paid off, as newly signed Congolese forward Chris Mugalu opened his account in the premiership with a goal on his debut start for CAPS United.

news.title: Agama FC strengthens promotion hopes with crucial victory
news.content:
Story by Tapiwa Machemedze
MOUNT Darwin-based side Agama is making waves in the Northern Region Soccer League Division One, having set a target for promotion into the top-flight league at the end of the season.
Agama FC edged Oden FC 1–0 at Pfura Stadium this Saturday to retain second position on the league table, where they are tied on 38 points with N’ombeyawora FC.
The decisive goal came late in the first half, courtesy of Alec Chiume.
“At first, the game was tough, but we made adjustments in the second half. We passed well, scored goals, and managed to maintain our lead,” Agama FC Captain, Tinashe Balakasi said.
Agama coach Paul Chimalizeni, who has been with the team for only nine days, winning three matches in the process, praised his players for staying focused on securing the sole ticket to the Premier Soccer League.
“As the new coach, I enjoy winning, and I am here to win the championship. Like any other coach, my goal is to win, that is the plain truth,” he said.
Oden FC coach Phillip Tutani, who is Chimalizeni’s predecessor, conceded that Agama was the better team on the day.
“They played very well, they are a good side. I wish them all the best,” Golden FC Coach Arthur Tutani said.

news.title: Sables eye 2027 World Cup qualification glory
news.content:
Story by Raynald Ngwarati
THE Zimbabwe senior fifteens rugby team, the Sables, have arrived in Uganda ahead of their Africa Cup title defence in the East African country which kicks off on the 8th of this month.
The reigning African champions touched down on Ugandan soil this Saturday, with their sights firmly set on replicating last year’s exploits to earn an automatic qualification ticket to the 2027 Rugby World Cup.
Facing stiff competition from eight other countries on the continental stage, Zimbabwe will open their campaign against Morocco on July 8and have retained most of the players who won the cup last year.
Speaking upon arrival in Uganda, Sables head coach Pieter Benade emphasised the importance of existing player chemistry in securing qualification for the World Cup for the first time since 1991.
“We are grateful to have the majority of the players from last year. So, we are hoping for continuity, and hopefully, the good memories from last year will keep the spirits high,” he said.
Zimbabwe has qualified for the global stage twice, first in 1987 and then in 1991.
The current squad, which broke a 12-year drought by winning the Rugby Africa Cup in 2024, is aiming to end a World Cup qualification jinx that has persisted for over three decades.

news.title: Chevrons seek historic test win against Proteas
news.content:
Story by Raynald Ngwarati
THE Zimbabwe senior men’s cricket team, the Chevrons, have a daunting task to level the two-match Test series against South Africa when the two nations face off in the second Test match beginning this Sunday at Queens Sports Club in Bulawayo.
Eying a historic win, the Chevrons need to be at their best to defeat the World Test champions in the second and final test match of the bilateral series.
After suffering a 328-run defeat in the first Test, Zimbabwe will need to overcome a bullish South African side that has gone for eleven test matches without tasting defeat since skipper Temba Bavuma took the reins.
The Proteas look sharper than ever with an ambitious young squad that is disciplined in all aspects of the game and ready to hunt at any given time.
The Chevrons will need to bring their A-game against the world champions if they are to break South Africa’s winning streak in Test Cricket.
